summary.p: Two manuscripts, by the same scribe, seem to have been bound together here.

The first and last folios, both unnmbered, contain a collection of mantras, along with some ritual instructions. The scribe uses a peculiar version of the oṃkāra symbol, turned 90 degrees counterclockwise.

Folios numbered 2-3, in between them, contain a fragment of the Nalodaya, a short poem variously attributed to Kālidāsa, Abhinavakālidāsa, or Ravideva, among others. Verses 1.4-1.15 are extant here. They are accompanied by a commentary in tripāṭha format, although the commentary occasionally spills out into the left and right margins as well. In addition, each verse is annotated interlinearly to show word breaks and to resolve external sandhi.

supportDesc.foliation: Western numerals, pencilled in on the mesh, bottom-right corner, recto.
supportDesc.condition: Large gaps due to damage. The paper has been sandwiched in thin mesh in order to preserve it.

layoutDesc.layout: Double margin lines on the left and right.

acquisition.p: Jean Filliozat indicates that this was part of acquisition number 3091, 10 May 1842. This refers to a group of manuscripts bought from Leclere libraire (perhaps Henri-Adrien Leclère).
